YOUNG: Doggin’ it? Was ‘spectin’ I’d git up to the lantern.
Well, sir, it’s the one them establishment fellers gave me--
What... Why’d yer last keeper leave?
You git some kinda peart outta molestin’ me?

Now look here, I ain’t never intended to be no housewife nor slave in takin’ this job. It ain’t right! These lodgings is more ramshackle than any shanty boy’s camp I ever seen. The queen of England’s own fancy housekeeper couldn’t do no better than what I done, ‘cause I tell you, I scrubbed this here place twice over, sir and- -
They're not going to see it in a Goddamn storm!
Ephraim Winslow. These last two weeks, I’d... well, I’d like it, sir, if you’d call me by my name.
Big timber. Up north. Canada ways.
Yessir. Spruce, tamarack... white pine. “Bush,” them folk up there call it.
Like you says, just had enough of trees, I guess.
Since I left Dad, well... I done every kind of work can pay a man. Some I ain’t near proud of.
No sir! Just can’t find a post I can take a real shine to, so I keep movin’ along. And I ain’t the kind to look back at what’s behind him, see.
No sir -- now look here, now -- I mean, nothin’ wrong with a man startin’ fresh, startin’ new, lookin’ to earn a living––
...like any man, tryin’ to settle down quiet-like with some earnings...
Say, why’s it bad luck to kill a gull?
Not as often as I might. But I’m God fearin’ -– if that’s what yer askin’.
Should pale death and treble dread make the... uh...
You feel shame when you lie with a woman?
Have it yer way... uh... Say, I never... I don’t know yer name.
To my friend Tom, and to gittin’ off this goddamned rock!
Look, maybe the tender, maybe she did come. We missed her, is all. I can take the dory out--
Yer just tryin’ to scare me.
Thought you said you broke it.
Yer leg. Catholic nuns, and such like.
No, no, no. No! And I says git off me, I says.

But they never listened... they’d never... if I had the chance, they’d never –- none of them Goddamned lily-livered Canadian bastards. Lack-gall cowards. Those bastard didn’t fight no revolution - – never –- and look at em! Cowards and he-women all of ‘em. Goddamn ‘em!
Never! Any day, breaking my back, working a man harder than two horses, but Winslow, Winslow... I told that dumb bastard...
Give me yer cant hook, I says to him, but foreman Winslow that goddamned Canady son-of-a-bitch fool bastard... always callin’ me a dog. A filthy dog.
Yeah, that bastard. “I’ll show you who’s a dog.”
He’s always raggin’ on me, like you. Damn fool nonsense.
How’d you find yourself off that grass island anyhow?
Yeah, that’s the trouble with Winslow.
The trouble with you is eatin’ grass without no teeth.
Yer sea maties’ teeth was fallen out--
Just... just, it seems powerful hard to eat grass without no teeth. Goats and sheeps and cows. Well now, they all got teeth, don’t they?
You rip it out and you swallow it.
Don’t be such an old bitch.
How could I possibly like the horseshit you fix us for supper?
Drunk since I first laid eyes on you.
Yer drunker than a Virginy fence.
Alright. Have it your way. I like yer cooking.
Didn’t wanna wake you, is all.
You ain’t even human no more. Workin’ apart from folks so long. What’d you lose?
Yer only tol’rable when yer dunk.

Come all you boys who wish to hear How we got up to the woods last year, Oh, into the sleigh we jacked our boots Our teamster pointed to the big blue spruce Timmy-ran-tin-ah Falla-doo-a-dah Rant-and-roar and drunk-on-the-way! Timmy-ran-tin-ah Falla-doo-a-dah--
No... It wasn’t that way, is all...
Look, I mean, look, Tom... don’t be working to twist words out of my head.
No. I don’t trust you at all.

And I had ‘im handy and helpless. Alone. Too far downstream. And I wanted to do ‘im in. I admit I did. Seein’ the back of his head. One swipe of the cant hook’d be all. It was... I didn’t... but I didn’t...
All I thought when he was done is,
You crazy son-of-a-bitch! You smashed up the life boat!
What’re you gonna do? Send for the lighthouse establishment?
I’ll report you. I know what you done...
And I got it all figgerd out, ‘cept what’s the secret mischief yer keepin’...
I’m tired out of listening to your damned-fool yarns and your Cap’n Ahab horseshit -- you sound like a goddamned parody. Givin’ and nagging orders like a spinster schoolmarm... and... and...
Well, it’s all horseshit, yer leg, and yer sea life, all of it. And I’m tired of it. If I hear one more word of horseshit coming from your foul, rotten tooth, smelly old mouth––
Shut up yer gum, Goddamn it -- I ain’t finished.

I’m sick of lookin’ at you, I’m sick of lookin’ at week-old food in yer beard starin’ me in the face like it ‘spects me of somethin’. You think yer so damned high and mighty cause yer a goddamned lighthouse keeper? Well, you ain’t a captain of no ship and you never was, you ain’t no general, no copper, you ain’t the president, and you ain’t my father -- and I’m sick of you actin’ like you is! I’m sick of yer orders! I’m sick of your laughing, your snoring, and your goddamned farts. Your damned goddamned farts. Goddamn yer farts! You smell like piss, you smell like jism, like rotten dick, like curdled foreskin, like hot onions fucked a farmyard shit-house. And I’m sick of yer smell. I’m sick of it! I’m sick of it, you goddamned drunk. You goddamned, no-account, drunken, son-of-a-bitch-bastard- liar! That’s what you are, you’re a goddamned drunken horse-shitting –- short -- shit liar. A liar!
No need to tell me, old timer.
Assistant slept late. Work below standard.
Assistant missing. Given to habitual ‘self-abuse’ in the supply shed.
Attempted to abandon his post. Assault. Theft.
Yer trying to ruin me?! I’m a hard worker! I am! I work as hard as any man!
Work as hard as a man and two horses, you said so yerself, I work like I’m a damn foreigner.

Please, please, let me into the light, old man, and I’ll show you what I can do for -- I can -- I can do better -- I can. I’ve learned so much from you. Another chance. Let me show you. Forgive and forgit, I says -- just let me into that lantern, is all, don’t make me beg--
Shut up! Shut up! Shut up!
Ain’t you never been to sea before, bark I says, bark!
Now, there’s a good boy. There’s a good dog.
Git in there, you old dog. Where you belong.
You do as I say, dog!
Shut up, dog. Polish yer brasswork.
Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul.
OLD: Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul.
Bad luck to leave a toast unfinished, lad.
Didn’t picture you was a readin’ man.
Then y’do as I say. That’s in yer book, too.

Aye. The cistern needs a-lookin’ to. One of yer duties, lad. Or didn’t y’read yerself about it? Polishin’, swabbin’. Swabbin’ and polishin’. You’ll clean the brass and the clockwork, and you can tidy the quarters after. There’s well- more to be mended outside.
When the fog clears, you’ll work through the dog watch--
It’s the mid watch that’s to dread, lad: night to morning. My watch.
Some new junior man I’m fixed with-- Y’act like y’never been to sea a’fore.
I’m meanin’ y’ain’t fit fer the wearin’ of it. See to yer duties. The light’s mine.
Tend to ‘em after the cistern. And the lamp, she needs oil.
Use this next time. Save you a helluva lotta trouble.
Then bring that drum back down the ladderwell where y’found it. ‘Less yer fixin’ to burn the whole light down.
Then see to the rest of yer duties. Yer behindhand already.
Yer too slow. You a dullard?
Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul.

Ah, find some chirk in ye, lad. Now is the time for gab and chatter. Y’best be enjoying it. Come a fortnight and the brace of us’ll be wantin’ to be ever silent as the tomb. Even to clap eyes on each other... It’ll make y’hotter than hell!

Y’ain’t. Y’ain’t. Aye, the Chicopee, a fine-un, she were. Clean-built and trig-lookin’! None more fleet in ‘64 than she... We were on the breaks -- a mutiny it were. And why, ask ye? Why? What’s the terrible part of the sailor’s life ask ye, lad? T’ain’t Cap’n, workin’ ‘em double-tide. Nay, no.

‘Tis when the workin’ stops when yer twixt wind and water. Doldrums. Doldrums. Eviler than the Devil. Boredom makes men to villains... And the water goes quick, lad... vanished. And what’s the answer? What be the cure? The only med’cine is drink. Drink, lad! Keeps them sailors happy, keeps ‘em agreeable, keeps ’em calm, keeps em–-
Curse me if there ain’t an old tar spirit somewheres in ye, lad.

Aye, went mad, he did. First a strangeness. A quietude. Then wild fancies struck him. Ravin’ ‘bout sirens, merfolk, bad omens and the like. In the end, no more sense left in him than a hen’s tooth. He believed there were some enchantment in the light.
He notioned St. Elmo did cast his very fire into it. Salvation, said he.
Best y’leave ‘em be. Bad luck to kill a sea bird.
Bad luck to kill a sea bird.
Pay me no mind, lad. None. Fix us up some coffee. Long night ahead. Drop o’coffee‘ll do us good.
You’ve been neglecting yer duties, lad!
And I say y’did nothin’ o’the sort.
Now that’s a good lad. That’s what
Oh what be the bane of a lightkeeper's life? What cause him to worry, to struggle and strife, What make him use cuss words, and beat at his wife? ‘Tis Brasswork.
What make him look ghastly, consumptive and thin? What rob him of health, of his vigor and vim? And cause him despair and drives him to sin.' ‘Tis Brasswork.
The oil containers I polish until, My poor back is broken, aching; and still...
Whitewash must be even, lad. Bright! Shinin’!
Like a silver whorehouse token. Give ‘em sailors a proper daymark.
They will after! And'll be glad to see it! Keep your temper now, lad. ‘Tis fine work. Yer makin’ high marks in me logbook. Them’s gospel!
I'll drop y’down a few feet.
Listen to ye, giving orders, lad.
Alright, alright... suits me just as fine, Ephraim Winslow. So, what brung such a one as you to this damnèd rock?
Winslow -– What brings you to this rock, Ephraim Winslow? What were yer work afore?
True what they say? “Forest far as the eye can see.”
Had enough of trees, that it, then?
Can’t say I blame ye. I hearn tell about that life. Hard goin’. Workin’ one man harder than two hosses, they say. No thankee. The sea, she’s the only situation wantin’ fer me.
Miss it? I ain’t never know’d anything but it.
Ain’t nothing what can touch it.

But can’t be draggin’ me old stump about...  Nay... not worth the trouble... now I’m a wickie and a wickie I is. I’m damn-well wedded to this here light, and she’s been a finer, truer, quieter wife than any a live- blooded woman.
Thirteen Christmases at sea... little ‘uns at home. She never forgave it.

Since we’re getting too friendly, Ephraim Winslow, tell me, what’s a timber man want with being a wickie? Not enough quiet for ye up north? Sawdust itching yer nethers? Foreman found ye too high-tempered for carrying an axe?
In ‘em’s the souls o’ sailors what met their maker.
Russian Tar once told me: yer cigarette cinder goes out, there be someone somewhere’s a-thinkin’ bad thoughts of ye.

Don’t be so darn foolish. It’s the calm afore the storm, Winslow. She were a gentle westerly wind yer cursin’. Only feels roughly ‘cause you don’t know nothin’ bout nothin’ and there ain’t no trees on this here rock like your Hudson Bay bush. Nor’Easterly wind’ll come soon a-blowin’ like Gabriel’s horn. Best board up them signal house winders.
‘Twill keep steady afore the tender comes in the morn, I ‘spect... but there’s dirty weather knockin’ about.
Somethin’ stirring in ye? Yer gettin’ off this island tomorry Winslow, don’t start grudgen me now.
Pull, pull, me good lad. Pull, Winslow!
Look at ‘em! Better than fin fishin’!
‘Tis no crime to take a snort now.
And bein’ our last afore relief, I never know’d an inspector what wouldn’t turn a blind eye, and I won’t take “no” for an answer.
When we're arrived on Bedford docks Them bloomers all comin’round in flocks Them pretty girls, we hear 'em say "Here comes Jack with his nine- month pay"
...and a pretty lass, she were, takin’ off her bonnet... but as I says, I’d broke me leg, and banged myself all up. It was to a nuns' hospital... All of them nuns were Catholics, I tell ye...

Aye, but I never went to Salem since without hoping that I should see her, for beddin’ down wer’nt the same since. I don't know, but if I was a-goin’ to begin me life over again... well, womenfolk are apt to be dreadful ashamed of it, anyhow.

Well, I’ll say it... I might even miss ye, Ephraim Winslow, yer fastly a true blue wickie in the making, you is. Thought one night you was bound to split me skull in twain, but yer a good-un. Why you’ll be workin’ the lamp in no time –
I’m the keeper of this station, lad.
My log is the only book on this rock--
I’m the keeper of the light, lad, I never let no man touch her--
Y’smell o’ shit. Best swab this mess afore the tender comes.
Y’do as yer told, lad! The quarters are dire.

‘Tis frost and snow and winter storm.  Go down ye blood red roses, go down!  And there’s many a ship lost round Cape Horn.  Go down ye blood red roses, go down!  Oh, ye pinks and posies... EIGHT... Go down!
Well, the captain he's o’er come with fear. Go down –-
The damp‘s got to the foodstuffs. The salt cod is out.
It’s been weeks ago since we missed her, Winslow. And I’ve been askin’ ye to ration fer weeks now, too, and you’ve kept barking at me like a mad dog, sayin’ you can “take the dory out”--
Don’t be losing yer head now.
No, it ain’t. And I ain’t wantin’ to be stranded here with some damned lunatic.
If we can wait out this storm.
In ‘75 ‘Ol Striker were marooned here for seven long months, he was. The storm died on the mainland but here, waters were too rageful neither to launch nor land.
Look at ye. Pretendin’. But ye well- know yer lot.
... their gums grew swollen, the color of bone, then to rot. Tarry blood oozed, teeth droppin’ to deck with none to hold on to.
Who, Winslow? The eaves be fallin’--
Raggin’? Who’s raggin’? What island? That’s the trouble with ye, Winslow.
Y’know how y’eat grass without haven’ yer teeth?
Ye rip it out and ye swallow it.
You’re drunk, you don’t know what yer talkin’--
Yer fond of me lobster, ain’t ye?
Let Neptune strike ye dead, Winslow!

Hark, Triton, Hark! Bellow, and bid our father, the sea king, rise up from the depths, full- foul in his fury, black waves teeming with salt-foam, to smother this young mouth with pungent slime...  ... to choke ye, engorging yer organs till ye turn blue and bloated with bilge and brine and can scream no more... only when, he, crowned in cockle shells with slithering tentacled tail and steaming beard, takes up his fell, be-finnèd arm -– his coral-tined trident screeches banshee-like in the tempest and runs you through the gullet, bursting ye, a bulging bladder no more, but a blasted bloody film now -- a nothing for the Harpies and the souls of dead sailors to peck and claw and feed upon, only to be lapped up and swallowed by the infinite waters of the dread emperor himself, forgotten to any man, to any time, forgotten to any god or devil, forgotten even to the sea... for any stuff or part of Winslow, even any scantling of your soul, is Winslow no more, but is now itself the sea.
Queer way to wear yer shoes.
Mm-hm. The sun is over the yardarm. Best find me some winks afore the day draws farther on.
Get to yer duties or I’ll give you a real keelhauling.
She swung her hips, she winked her eyes, that sassy little whore, So I took her in, I gave her gin, and danced her on the floor!
Oh 'round and 'round the sofa, boys, wasn't it a show She grabbed hold of my bobstay and she wouldn't let it go!

Oh, where have all the evenings gone? Oh, where is the ale and whisky I’ve tasted? Gone the same way as the pay I done wasted, On a Monday morning. If but the birds were gin, If but the sun was a hearty reveler, If I might give someone else me liver, On a Monday morning.
My lover she lies asleep, My lover is warm, and her heart is mellow,
Don’t be spilling any of yer beans to me.
Never did like being confided to.
Yer guilty conscience is ever as tiresome-borin’ as any a guilty conscience.
Shut up yer own rag box.
Certain, says I! I’ll report ye, I’ll bring the inspector up--
Who’s reportin’ who? Ephraim Winslow? Or Thomas Howard?

Jesus, Mary and Joseph, Tommy. Last night you made a confession ‘twould make a saint swear. I don’t have nothin’ to confess, but you, Tommy, a-spillin’ yer beans... now look what it’s done to ye. It’s made ye mad. I knew ye was mad when y’smashed up the life boat just now, a-chasing me with an axe, tryin’ to kill ‘Ol Tom. Don’t y’trust me, Tommy?
Better hand me the dinner knife you pocketed. Y’aint safe with it.
Look at yer shiverin’. Yer so mad, y’know not up from down. How long have we been on this rock? Five week? Two days? Where are we? Help me to recollect, who are you again, Tommy?

I’m probably a fig’ment of your ‘magination. This rock is a fig’ment of yer ‘magination, too. Yer probably wand’rin’ through a grove of tag alders, up in north Canady, like a frostbitten maniac a- talkin’ to yerself, knee-deep in the snow, the blizzard overtakin’ ye.
Be my guest. You’ll get drowned.
Fiery pit! Ain’t there no justice left in this world?
It started as a sliver of a cut is all...
... from the forestaysail when we shoved off...
... his chops was locked tighter than an anchor bend--
What were it yer accused me of? Y’already told me y’had me figgerd--
Y’have a way with words, Tommy.

Look at ye, handsome lad, with eyes bright as a lady. Come to this rock playin’ the tough, ye make me laugh with yer false grum. Ye pretended to some mystery in yer quietudes, but there ain’t no mystery, yer an open book. A picture, says I. A painted actress screaming in the footlights, a bitch what wants to be coveted for nothin’ but being born, cryin’ bout the silver spoon what should’ve been yers. Now look at ye cryin’.
Boo! Boo! What’re y’to do? Look at ye. Look at ye. Will y’kill me? Will ye? Will y’kill me like y’done that gull?
Would ye best me then? If y’break,
Y’wish to see what’s in that lantern?
Y’said yer a God fearin’ man, Tommy?  Them’s truth, Tommy!
and cast them down to Davy Jones. And others, still blind, yet in it see all divine graces and to Fiddler’s Green sent, where no man is suffered to want and toil, but is
OLD AND YOUNG: Hurrah, we're homeward bound, Hurrah, we're homeward bound!
Hurrah, we're homeward bound, Hurrah, we're homeward bound!
YOUNG AND OLD: Doodle let me go, me girls, doodle let me go, Hurrah, me yaller girls, doodle let me go!
